segments.text: Go ahead and start talking in interviews.
Has a 15 second protective device on this thing.
Sometimes works, sometimes doesn't.
Okay, would you explain then please your interest in the Louisiana, Missouri plant?
Yes.
I came to Morgantown in 1946.
The station here was established under the Synthetic Liquid Fuels Act.
We occupied space on campus at West Virginia University.
And then Congress authorized a permanent station for Morgantown.
That must have been about 1950, 51.
My memory is fuzzy on the dates.
It was formally dedicated the station on College Ferry Road in 1954.
I came to study gas purification, purification of synthesis gas.
I don't know when the Louisiana, Missouri plant was authorized to be constructed.
It probably was the late 40s.
You probably got this information from telling me that you didn't even know about that.
But my job at the time
was to review the German purification technology, and more specifically, to improve upon it.
And our job was to obtain on the bench scale and on a small planet scale data that could be used in Louisiana, Missouri.
Although they had committed themselves to the German purification process as such,
The information that we were to supply to them was to improve the operation of the plant at Louisiana, Missouri.
The only time I've been at Louisiana, Missouri was during the dedication of the plant.
As I recall, their purification consisted of a liquid scrubber followed by
a process called the soda iron process, the function of it being to remove the organic sulfur compounds, the liquid scrubber to remove hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide.
And it may have been that between the liquid scrubber and the soda iron, they had an activated carbon vessel to remove
gum formers, which would otherwise interfere with the operation of the soda iron.
You must realize that, I think this is correct, that all German gasification processes were at atmospheric pressure, essentially, as was their gas purification.
The Louisiana plant, the gas purification, was designed to operate under pressure.
In fact, the first pressure gasification of coal in the world was done here in Morgantown back in 1946, 1947.
So all of my gas purification work was under 300 pounds pressure.
Since they were committed to the soda iron process,
I didn't feel that there was any need to look at that in the laboratory, since they were going to operate the plant anyway and get the data out there.
So, we looked at, well the Germans had what they call Alkazdik, that's A-L-K-A-Z-I-D.
and an alkazid M. I don't recall the chemical composition, but one was to selectively take out the hydrogen sulfide, and one was to remove simultaneously hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide.
And the need for taking out hydrogen sulfide selectively is that when you regenerate your liquid solution, you get the hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide off as an off-gas.
And to process that in what was called the class process for converting hydrogen sulfide to elemental sulfur, you had to do something with the hydrogen sulfide.
You needed a high concentration of hydrogen sulfide with respect to carbon dioxide.
So therefore, you had to selectively absorb hydrogen sulfide rather than carbon dioxide.
But we didn't get involved in any of the German liquid scrubbing agents.
We looked at those available in the United States, and the ones we concentrated on were those made by Gerger Corporation, and they were called mono, di, and triethanolamine.
The triethanolamine was the selective agent, so we concentrated on that, although we looked at the other two also.
And the Louisiana recommendation, Louisiana, Missouri, was to use triethanolamine as their liquid scrubber.

In the meantime, we were looking for better ways of removing organic sulfur rather than the soda iron process, because I had priced the cost of the soda iron as prepared in the United States, and it was an enormous figure.
Of course, during the war, the Germans would not
Economics was no problem.
There was no concern.
So, as I recall, they used this sort of iron.
When it became spent, they simply threw it away.
So it was way too expensive.
So we looked at other methods, and we looked at activated carbon under pressure as an absorbent for organic sulfur compounds.
Now based on the German data, their most difficult organic sulfur compound to remove was thiophene.
So we started out on the assumption that thiophene would be our more difficult, most difficult thing to remove, compound to remove.
So we tried activated carbon and it was an excellent adsorbent for thiophene.
Let me interrupt for a moment.
How would thiophene have gotten into the gas, except as a catalyst, as part of the catalyst?
Or from the coal.
From the coal itself?
Yeah.
I see.
Most of the organic sulfur compounds in coal are of a thiophenic nature.
Oh, I didn't know that.
Yes.
Most of the organic sulfur compounds are tied up as thiophenes.
And the simplest of these thiophenes is thiophene per se.
four carbons, four hydrogens, and a sulfur anyway.
Yeah, C4H4S.
So we were very elated when we found activated carbon responded so beautifully to thiophene and also that the activated carbon when it became spent could be very easily
be regenerated or be vivified simply by heating it with a hot inert gas.
And you've got back the full capacity of it for subsequent use.

Concurrent with that, we thought we would look at methods for removing the hydrogen sulfide and organic sulfur simultaneously so that we can eliminate the scrubbing system, which was used for taking out hydrogen sulfide.
So we had at that time a consultant called Dr. Huff, who had developed this catalyst, which consisted of the oxides of copper, chromium, and vanadium.
And we studied that.
It absorbed the hydrogen sulfide 100%.
There was nothing in the F1 gas.
It reduced the organic sulfur, the usual forms,
carbon oxisulfide, carbon disulfide.
They were captains.
But the thiophene was too refractory.
It didn't touch the thiophene at all.
But it did work beautifully.
And then when it started passing sulfur, then we simply regenerated it with air and got it back to the oxides.
Then when it was put back on stream, these oxides
just by the nature of them, were reduced by the synthesis gas to the element.
And I think at the time, we utilized 10% of the synthesis gas for the reduction step, just the way it worked.
Well, this became uneconomical then, so we dropped that.
In fact, we dropped the idea of removing hydrogen sulfide and ordinary sulfur simultaneously.
About that time, the gasifier on campus at Beachhurst Avenue was put into operation, and as whereas we were operating under slagging conditions, and whereas the German processes were non-slagging,
And therefore, in order to operate under slagging conditions, it required a much higher temperature.
I think the island gas was something like 2,400 degrees Fahrenheit.
So when we went to analyze the gas to find out what organic sulfur compounds were there, unfortunately, now, there was no thiophene.
The temperatures obviously cracked it down to hydrogen sulfide and methane, perhaps.
I don't know.
And the only organic sulfur compound present in the gas was that as carbonyl sulfide, COS.
This was of some concern because whereas thiophene is a liquid at ambient temperatures, COS is a gas.
So we were concerned that the activated carbon could effectively take out a gaseous organic sulfur compound.
So we concentrated our efforts on that and found that it didn't work very nicely.
I think I recall a rough cost estimate of something like the activated carbon cycle was something like two-tenths of a cent per thousand cubic feet.
It was extremely cheap.
We investigated a wide variety of charcoals, those made from coconut shale, which back then was selling for something like $1.25 a pound, I think.
And then we also looked at some
That one that was prepared from coal, supplied by somebody on Nimble Island in Pittsburgh, Columbia Carbon Company, I believe.
But anyway, it was relatively inexpensive, quite inexpensive compared to the coconut shell, and it worked almost as well, so we concentrated on that.
And have these processes been adopted by IGT, let's say, in manufacturing high gas in Chicago?
Comper's company used the activated carbon for absorbing, adsorbing organic sulfur.
I can't tell you where the plant was.
But the synthane plant
At Brewston, the coal gasification plant uses activated carbon for taking out organic sulfur compounds.
At Louisiana and Missouri, I think this is correct, they operated the soda iron.
They developed a hot spot, and I think the vessel ruptured.
Did McGee or Kattel mention this?
They said the vessel ruptured.
Yeah, and I don't think it was put back into operation.
because by that time we had found that activated carbon could do what soda iron could do.
So our recommendation was simply a liquid scrubber, triethanolamine, and of course the liquid scrubber, you cannot operate it to remove all the hydrogen sulfide.
It becomes uneconomical.
In fact, I don't think you could reduce the vapor pressure sufficient that you could take it all out anyway.
And we did various

efficiency studies to determine the optimum hydrogen sulfide to be left in the gas leaving the liquid scrubber and this came out to be about 25 grains per 100 cubic feet so this we removed by the inexpensive classical

method the old iron oxide box it's simply iron oxide on wood shavings and it cleans it right up beautifully so we recommended the liquid scrubber followed by iron oxide followed by activated carbon and this gets your total sulfur down probably
certainly less than a tenth of a grain per hundred cubic feet.
And of course we were interested in sulfur even lower than that because at the time we had a cooperative agreement with, I think it was Southern Natural Gas, to study the
effective sulfur on the activity of a nickel catalyst for converting hydrogen and carbon monoxide to methane.
So we purified the gas over a wide range of sulfur concentrations.
established the life of the catalyst with respect to the emits sulfur concentration.
So we were interested in getting down as far as we could.
I think the specifications for Fischer-Tropsch at the time was something like a tenth of a grain per 100 cubic feet of total sulfur, and that's what we were shooting at.
Of course, we preferred lower because nickel catalyst is much more prone to be poisoned by sulfur than the Fischer-Tropsch catalyst, either the iron or the cobalt.
So that's about the extent.
As I say, the unfortunate thing is that I don't think there are any data on the purification at Louisiana, Missouri, with the exception of one paper.
by a man by the name of Wilmot, and I think this was limited to the liquid scrubber.
And he's located now in Venice, Florida, if I'm correct?
He left here and went to Australia, to retire in Australia, and then he came back, and I don't know where he is.
But as far as I, to my knowledge, that's the only
piece of literature on the Louisiana gas purification system.
Which, as I told you at the front, is unfortunate, but that's just the way it is.
I get the impression that the view of the German documents gave you a substantial edge.
The thiophene, for instance, you knew immediately where the problem was going to lie.
Which didn't materialize, of course.
Would you say that the German documents were of any substantial help?
Not as far as gas purification is concerned, since we didn't adopt any of it.
And again, since we were operating under pressure, and all there was was an atmospheric pressure, it didn't apply.
And of course, the liquid scrubbing agents that they used, we were not interested in because they weren't manufactured in this country.
And from the data I saw, they were in no way superior to the ethanol amines.
So I can't really say no that they were of that much help.
In fact, they were too expensive.
They were helpful in this respect as far as establishing specifications for the purified gas with respect to the Fischer-Trump synthesis.
They were in that respect helpful.
But as far as the technology is concerned, I can't say it was much help.
How long were you working on purification gas?
Two, three years?
From 1946 to 1955.
So you really worked through the closure of the Louisiana, Missouri plant?
Yes.
Did there seem to be... Did the personnel of your own mind seem to be agitated that the Louisiana, Missouri plant closed?
I can't speak for others, but I certainly was.
I mean, I had devoted...
Up until that time, five years of research to be utilized in Louisiana, Missouri, I never was.
So it was a discomfort to me.
And, well, it's just unfortunate.
But at the time, well, when this station was, when we occupied space on campus, there were two stations in the Pittsburgh area.
one on Forbes Street in the Oakland area of Pittsburgh, and one at Brewston, Pennsylvania.

And when we tried to get a permanent station established in Morgantown, there was a lot of hassle among the two stations, between the two stations in Pittsburgh, feeling it was unnecessary for a third center to be established within a distance of 75 miles.
But we were established primarily as a coal gasification center, whereas Brewston was primarily coal hydrogenation.
And it remains that way pretty much today, that way.
But anyway, we did get the station here in Morgantown.
And I recall that when the Louisiana, Missouri plant was brought up,
It was strongly opposed by Dr. Storch, who was the head of the Brewston station at the time.
Dr. Storch was a real scientist and more or less like fundamental research in addition to the small pilot scale work that we're doing in Brewston.
And I think it was his opinion that we were going to too large of a scale.

Then in 1952, I'm sure this is a coincidence, but in 1952, with the change of the administration, there was a massive change in the personnel in the Washington office, and this Dr. Storch then became the head in Washington.
But I say I think it's a mere coincidence that Louisiana was closed at the time that he went to Washington.
But as I say, he did oppose the construction of the plant, but no one man, after it had gone along that long of a period of time, could be influential in closing it down.
I just think it happened to be a coincidence.
Why do you think it closed down?
Well, as I was telling Dr. Kramer on the phone, I really don't know.
No one talked about it.
I think that...
Based on cost estimates, which I'm not familiar with, you're more familiar with this than I am, I think it was becoming more or less competitive with crude petroleum.
And whether the oil lobby had anything to do with it, I just don't know.
But I have my feelings.
As I was telling Dr. Kramer on the phone, at that time, the petroleum industry wouldn't even look at the coal industry.
They were absolutely enemies, so to speak, completely divorced of each other.
And then, as you know how things have turned out, I don't know how much of the coal now is controlled by those trolleys and such.
But it's unfortunate that it happened that way, but as I told also Dr. Kramer, I don't think we'd be in the situation we are today
if that plant had been allowed to continue to operate.
What did you do after you stopped experimenting with gas?
At that time, they had developed at the Denver, Colorado station, I believe it was, one of the Colorado stations, a process that they call low temperature carbonization of coal.
As opposed to coke oven operation that operates something like 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit, low temperature carbonization operates about 950 degrees Fahrenheit.
Therefore, the tars that evolve from the coal, whereas they are cracked in the coke oven to make gas, they come out as a tar liquid in the low temperature carbonization.
So they put up a plant, Alcoa, in conjunction with the Texas Power Light Company, put up a low temperature carbonization plant in Texas.
Rockdale, Texas, I believe.
And I suppose it's hindsight.
They didn't know what to do with the tar.
You couldn't burn it for its fuel value.
Otherwise, that wouldn't be enough to defray the cost of the expense of carbonizing coal.
And the purpose of carbonizing the coal was to get a char that you could generate power with in a conventional boiler.
So you had to have a profit on this tar, at least to defray the expenses of converting the coal into the char.
So we looked at it as a source of chemicals.
And we worked on that for approximately 10 years.

The upshot of that was that at the time there was a big hassle about biodegradable detergents and we knew that biodegradable detergents could be made by reacting benzene with a long chain olefin with the double bond on the last carbon.
Fortunately, this material from Texas, the tar we were working with was from malignite coal, and it had about 12% of this type of olefin.
So we extracted these and made biodegradable detergents.
That was one of our products.
And then we made carbon black, carbon electrodes, phthalic and malic anhydrides.
But anyway, when we found out the yields of all these things, as I recall, we figured out that a 2 million ton a year carbonization plant, the market would be completely flooded with these chemicals.
Completely flooded.
So after we found out that, we discontinued that.
And then we... Why would that be a disadvantage?
No.
Flood the market.
You didn't have the consumer.
Oh, I see.
One small plant like that, and you produce enough biodegradable detergents to the country.
So all interest was lost in that, whether it'll be, oh, we know that it is a source of jet fuels to try to get a premium value product out of it.
Probably, if it ever comes back into being again, it'll be a source of liquid fuels.
In fact, we did some work on that.
And it converts very nicely to a synthetic petroleum.
So if it ever, if it ever revived, it'll probably be the end product that you can use for it.
Then we made a complete flip-flop after getting all this organic chemistry.
We completely got involved in inorganic chemistry by looking at the minerals of coal, the mineralogy of coal, and specifically the effect that they have on the various conversion products, processes.
Unfortunately, we didn't get to complete that to my satisfaction.

I wanted to find out what effect these minerals in a variety of coals with different mineral constituents, what effect this would have on the rate of gasification, what effect it would have on our service of catalyst and coal hydrogenation.
This work, I think, is currently being done at Penn State now under Dr. Gidham.
And I think it's a very fruitful area of research.

I feel that in the future, when a person buys coal, that the specifications that now exist, such as the BTU value, the ash content, the sulfur content, will actually, there will be limits on certain mineral constituents.
so much cadmium, so much mercury, because these do volatilize after the atmosphere.
So I think that the mineralogy of coal will get involved in the future specifications of coal.
And indeed, some coals that we looked at, one particular one had more tin in it than some of the tin ores that they're processing to make tin.
And one had more copper in it than some of the copper ores that they're processing.
So anyway, based on that mineralogy work we did, sort of serendipity I guess, we got a contract with NASA to look at the lunar samples.
So we had lunar rocks from Apollo 11, 12, 14, and 15.
So of course we got a lot of publicity out of that.
And then when that was completed...
I just have a curiosity.
What is lunar rock like?
I'll never in my life meet somebody else who would send a piece of slag.
Lava.
In fact, the composition is very close to volcanic lava.
But...
We put it on display out here at the station for the public, and we never saw their faces drop so much when they saw it.
And then we had some under the microscope, and there you could really see the various minerals and the various colors and the purples and the pinks and the reds and what have you.
So that sort of helped it along as far as the public was concerned.
Was there anything unusual about that lava, that slab?
It's the same kind of thing that you could find anywhere else.
No carbon, no metal.
Just a mixture of calcium, magnesium, silicon oxides, iron.
There was a higher percentage of titanium than we find here on Earth, but not that much different.
Not that much different.
I'll never meet anyone again in my life who examined more rocks, I'm sure.
Well, you should, from Texas, go over to Houston.
And then we...
got involved in some co-hybridization work on a very nominal scale.
And then where did you go?
Right here.
Right, okay.
That ticket was then retirement.
Right.
Okay.
Have any more questions you'd like to ask Dr. Cranford?
I'd like to inquire, you mentioned to me you had a short exchange with Secretary Warren.
Yes.
On the closing of the plant.
Yes.
He, uh, he was in Morgantown, visiting the station, shortly after we moved to the interior, I think, and we had lunch at a restaurant in town.
And, uh, I don't know how the subject was brought up, but I mentioned that Louisiana was very planned, and that, uh, I thought it was a pity that it was shut down.
And that's when he made the remark that, do you think the government starts research programs and then, uh,
doesn't get sufficient information from them.
And I said, well, on this particular case, that was the case.
But the thing that also disturbs me is that we're putting up more and more of these plants.
In all my reading of the literature, I don't see anybody referring or using any references to the Louisiana, Missouri plan.
